Award.AwardTitle: A Systematic Approach to Increase the Success Rates of Engineering and Technology Students at an Urban Community College

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering technology (ET) project model is designed to increase the success rates of ET students, especially underrepresented minorities and disadvantaged veterans. The effort is supported by Morgan State University (MSU), Capitol College, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI), Carnegie Mellon University (CMU), Juxtopia LLC, Lockheed Martin Corporation, the AMTEK Company, Baltimore Gas & Electric (BGE), Advanced Module Inc., NASA Goddard Center, National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE), Career Communication Groups (CCG), and the Maryland Center for Veterans Education and Training (MCVET). To achieve the project goals, the ET model is increasing success rates of ET students by: (1) implementing an Associate of Science in Electrical Engineering (ASE); (2) setting up a state-of-the-art electrical engineering laboratory by upgrading the existing electronics laboratory at the college; (3) developing curriculum materials using the RPI Mobile Studio for the first two years of electrical engineering and electronics technology courses; (4) revisiting the existing engineering and technology curriculum at the college to ease the transition for students moving between engineering and technology programs; (5) developing strong, mathematics centered and ET focused advising and activities; (6) creating a career pathway from ET programs to the MSU School of Engineering for an engineering related baccalaureate degree, and from the ET programs to Capitol College for a technology related baccalaureate degree; (7) providing internship and job opportunities to ET graduates; and (8) introducing ET concepts to underserved and disadvantaged 11th and 12th graders in the Baltimore City Public School System (BCPSS) and veterans, and recruiting them into ET programs.

The expected outcomes of this project are to: (1) produce a nationally ready math centered ET advising model; (2) implement a new ASE program with 50 students enrolled at the end of the project; (3) produce 10 more graduates annually with higher GPAs in Robotics/CIS/CADD programs; (4) implement a career pathway to MSU and Capitol College for at least 15 ET graduates; (5) provide internship and job opportunities to 90% of the ET graduates; (6) recruit 20% more currently enrolled students and 100% more veterans into ET programs; (7) offer ET seminars to 1000 students annually who are enrolled in underserved high schools and MCVET; (8) provide scholarships to selected ET students annually, and (9) increase the success rates in targeted ET programs by an average of 20 to 25%.

The intellectual merit of the project is the development of a nationally designed and systematic model that is increasing the success rates in ET through innovative degree programs, systematic advising, enhanced articulations, improved developmental math education, and reliable career pathways. To achieve these goals, the approach is facilitating an academic collaboration among two-year community colleges, public secondary schools, four-year colleges and universities, various organizations, and industry.

The project is demonstrating broader impacts by first improving ET education for a significant number of underserved and disadvantaged students. Secondly, the project is motivating an increased number of community college students and veterans to pursue an engineering or technology profession. Thirdly, the project is establishing a national dissemination ready bridge model between engineering and technology majors in urban community college settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary of the Outcomes of Award DUE-1203803

At the end of the fourth year of the BCCC ATE Grant DUE-1203803, the proposed goal – to increase the success rates of Engineering/Technology (ET) students, especially underrepresented minorities and disadvantaged veterans, has been achieved with the following outcomes:

Project Outcomes or Findings Addressing the Intellectual Merit

1. The newly developed ASE-EE program provides a floating mechanism for students to switch between ASE-EE and Robotics/Mechatronics majors based on students’ mathematics performance. In average, two students per year switched from Robotics/Mechatronics to ASE-EE and four students per year switched from ASE-EE to Robotics/Mechatronics. Eighty-three percent (83%) of the students completed the program within two and half years. This percentage is significant more than the average success rate of either Robotics/Mechatronics or ASE-EE.

2. Three articulation agreements between BCCC and Morgan State University (MSU) and two articulation agreements between BCCC and Capitol Technology University (CTU) are implemented during the funding period. These agreements increased the student transfer rate by 15% compared to May 2013 data.

3. Student Support/Advising Activities

4-Year University Campus Tour/Visit – ~300 BCCC ET students participated, 90%+ provided positive feedbacks.

Field Trips to STEM Companies and Organizations – ~250 BCCC ET students participated, 90%+ provided positive feedbacks.

STEM Conferences – ~200 BCCC ET students participated, 85% of the students provided positive feedbacks.

Guest Speakers – 12 guest speakers spoke to ~800 BCCC STEM students, 77% of the students provided positive feedbacks

4-Year School Ambassador – 200+ BCCC ET students participated, 88% of BCCC students provided positive feedbacks.

Mathematics-centered Activities – Include math awareness week, math circle friends, Just-In-Time Self-study (JiTS), and Robotics Word Problems (RWP).

Math Awareness Week: ~750 STEM students participated, 82% of the students provided positive feedbacks.

Math Circle Friends: ~160 pairs of students participated. It was found that the mean math GPA of ET students who participated in the Math Circle Friends was  1.06 grade points better on 4.0 grade point system than the mean math GPA of ET students who did not participate in the Math Circle Friends.

JiTS: 382 BCCC STEM students participated. It was found that students (~270) with consistent JiTS participation scored 0.9 grade points better on 4.0 grade point system than students without consistent JiTS participation.

Project Outcomes or Findings Addressing Broader of Impacts

1. Recruitment effort reached out to 2000+ Baltimore City Public School System (BCPSS) Students, 4000+ BCCC developmental math students, 2000+ BCCC General Studies students, and 200+ disadvantaged veterans. The overall ET enrollment at BCCC increased by approximately 3.2%.

2. Graduation, Internship, Job Placement and Transfer Students

Graduation - The total number of ET graduates during the funding period has increased by 16.1%.

Internship – The project helped 11 ET students find internships in STEM related fields via the academic partnership and industrial partnership developed by this ATE project.

Job Placement – The project helped many ET graduates find full time engineering related jobs via the BCCC/Employer Partnership developed or maintained by this ATE project. Specifically, at least 10 students graduated from BCCC robotics program and were hired by the industry partners (Amazon/JLL, Lockheed Martin, and Berry Plastics).

Transfer Students – The project helped more than 40 ET students transfer to 4-year schools via articulation agreements developed or upgraded by the ATE project. The number of students who transfer to 4-year schools has increased by 15%.

3. Community Outreach Effort includes BCCC STEM community Day, Sponsoring BCPSS Robotics team, serving as STEM advisory board member at local community centers, etc.

4.      Faculty/Staff Professional Development

The ATE project sponsored or help sponsored more than 40 professional development activities for BCCC faculty and staff.

5.      Institutional resources that form infrastructure

BCCC Robotics lab is upgraded to a robotics/mechatronics lab. BCCC Electronics Lab is upgraded to an electrical engineering lab.

BCCC’s Student Success Center used the college’s funds to hire a full time adviser to help students with stress managements and social challenges in Fall 2013.

Due to the successful operation of the ATE project, BCCC has converted the grant-supported ASE professor position to State PIN position.


Last Modified: 12/05/2016
Modified by: Yun Liu
